Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Integrative Biomedical Nanotechnology Laboratory Course

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this NUE in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Integrative Biomedical Nanotechnology Laboratory Course", at the Ohio State University (OSU), under the direction of Dr. Yi Zhao, is to develop a laboratory course for biomedical engineering undergraduates which synergistically integrates discrete pieces of nanotechnology education in traditional engineering disciplines and offers hands-on experience to students in this highly multidisciplinary field.

Besides the immediate benefits to biomedical engineering undergraduates at OSU, the outcome of this educational development will be applicable to a wider public audience. Dissemination to other BME educators will be through Big 10 BME exchange talk, educational conferences, publications in educational journals and global educational collaborations. The laboratory course emphasizing connections between hands-on experience and fundamental knowledge/principles of nanotechnology will provide a paradigm for undergraduate education in other multidisciplinary fields. Moreover, the dissemination to K-12 students will be implemented through the established Engineers in Motion program where grade appropriate versions of the experimental modules will be designed to match the educational background of the K-12 students involved. The proposed integrative biomedical nanotechnology laboratory course is expected to enhance work force development and create new opportunities for biomedical engineering undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nowadays nanotechnology is one of the most fascinating scientific disciplines that have long-lasting societal and commercial impacts. A comprehensive understanding of nanoscience and nanotechnology, however, often requires substantial knowledge in physics, chemistry and/or engineering, as well as extensive hands-on experimental experience. Such experience is not always accessible to undergraduate students due to the need for cleanroom environment, special facilities and high operational cost. This NUE project develops an interactive laboratory experience for biomedical engineering undergraduate students. This laboratory experience integrates discrete pieces of nanotechnology education in traditional engineering disciplines and offers hands-on experience to students. In particular, this project builds an infrastructure and allows students to design, fabricate, characterize, and test micro/nanofluidic systems in non-cleanroom environment for addressing designated and self-selected biomedical issues. The students participated in this project has been successfully demonstrated prototypes; and gained fundamental knowledge, technological skills, and entrepreneur mindset. Such experience is beneficial for their future career in nanoscience and nanotechnology. The outcome of this project includes the following items:

  • An infrastructure for sustainable implementation of the laboratory experience during and beyond the federal support period;
  • A standard experimental protocol and education framework designed to fit the learning curve of undergraduate students;
  • Student achievement including successful establishment of a start-up company, presentations and publications, placement in graduate schools and industries in relevant engineering disciplines

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2014
Modified by: Yi Zhao
